Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: Pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, the Court may modify a custody order upon a showing of a substantial and material change in circumstances.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The case of Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), establishes that a material change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child is a key factor in custody modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case, not a custody‑modification case, and it does not articulate a requirement of a “material change in circumstances” as a prerequisite to modifying custody. The opinion focuses on how to determine the child’s best interests when a custodial parent seeks to remove children from the Commonwealth, adopting the “real advantage” standard and discussing best‑interests factors. It nowhere frames the analysis as a custody modification requiring proof of a material change in circumstances, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child . . . and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”
